application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Understanding Game-Theoretic Algorithms: The Game Matters .=
Yoav Shoham Stanford University, Stanford, USA .=
Kevin Leyton-Brown University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada .=
Game Theory is useful in many areas of CS Can model multiagent interactions arising in: .=
GT also gives rise to some very interesting computational problems .=
compute a sample Nash equilibrium multiagent adaptation (learning) .=
So far: very few theoretical results are available even fewer empirical studies .=
1. A database of classes of games discussed in the literature .=
distinguishes between generative and non- generative sets .=
2. Implementation of generators for these classes .=
Not to be confused with Gambit a library of GT software .=
Searched through hundreds of books and papers Game Theory, CS, Political Science, Economics etc. .=
We identified 122 interesting sets of games .=
71 of these admit finite-time generative procedures the rest are either too broad or defined implicitly .=
e.g. games with a pure strategy NE .=
Sets vary from tiny to huge Prisoners’ Dilemma games compactly representable as graphical games .=
GAMUT 1.0 contains games that can reasonably be stored in normal form .=
How are the games related? (Weakly) Symmetric generative sets .=
Games Pure-strategy equilibrium other sets Equilibria Are .=
Pareto Ordered underline more subsets in database Compact Graphical (Strongly) Games Symmetric Games .=
Games; No Dominant Equilibrium Tree Structured Strategies .=
Battle of the Sexes Arms Races Matching .=
Games Location Centipede Games Grab the .=
Why not generate payoffs at random? all classes of interest that we discovered are non- generic w.r.t. uniformly random sampling .=
General lessons of empirical algorithmics: algorithms’ behavior varies substantially across “reasonable” input distributions in practice, structure is at least as important as problem size .=
uniformly-random inputs often have very different computational properties .=
How was GAMUT built? Implemented in Java Focus on extensibility and ease of use .=

Most important entity is a Generator 35 Java classes suffice to generate games from our 71 sets can pick generators from subset/intersection of classes according to our taxonomy can create subdistributions by partially settings parameters .=
Other basic entities include Outputs, Graphs, Functions Incorporates many utilities: .=
powerful parameter handling mechanism fixed-point conversion and normalization ability to sample parameters at random .=
Goal: demonstrate empirical variance w.r.t different instance distributions .=
Total of over 120 CPU-days of data .=
Algorithms tend to be very complex Gambit: a comprehensive software package .=
both use iterated removal of dominated strategies .=
All have worst-case exponential lower-bounds not known how tight these bounds actually are .=
complexity class for the problem is unknown .=
focus on differences due to structure .=
many, but not nearly all, of GAMUT distributions .=

Such variation occurs at different problem sizes .=
not always clear what the goals are .=
ignores strategic aspects and opponent adaptation .=
report average payoffs over the final 10,000 rounds .=
9 pairings all pairings (including self); as both players .=
averaged over 10 runs for each pairing .=
Algorithm parameters fixed tried to match those reported in literature .=
Lots of possible metrics could be considered .=
pairwise: fraction of time one algorithm is better than another .=
in both metrics, results differ across distributions! .=

GAMUT is a comprehensive test suite .=
capable of generating games from many classes .=
Choice of test data is extremely important .=
experiments show high runtime variation across different classes of games for several state-of-the-art algorithms and two computational problems .=
Behavior of game-theoretic algorithms is still poorly understood .=
we hope GAMUT will be used to address this and more! .=

Runtime Distributions: Summary • Distribution of runtimes varies significantly .=
across inputs – cannot be inferred based on knowing algorithm and .=
input size • Some games solved in preprocessing • Games taxonomically related seem to have .=
more similar distributions • Algorithms appear to be significantly different .=
from each other – runtime variation is not specific to any single .=
In order to generate and perform computation on games we must be clear about: .=
1. Semantics: a game is defined by (players, actions, payoffs) .=
2. Syntax: representations may include Normal Form, Extensive Form, Graphical Games, etc. can be compact, complete .=
Not uncontroversial in GT less controversial for computational purposes .=
In GAMUT 1.0 we focus on games representable compactly in normal form .=
